results.headline: ‘Viva Riva!’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Viva Riva!

results.summary_short: In “Viva Riva!” Djo Tunda Wa Munga, the Congolese writer and director, repackages the revenge thriller with distinctive African beats.

results.headline: ‘Trollhunter’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trollhunter

results.summary_short: “Trollhunter,” the Norwegian director André Ovredal’s clever and engaging mock documentary.

results.headline: ‘Reversion’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reversion

results.summary_short: In Mia Trachinger’s bleak “Reversion,” characters are mutants who cannot sense the passage of time; the present, future and past merge for them.

results.headline: Trouble Ahead: Director Falls for Leading Lady

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Road to Nowhere

results.summary_short: Monte Hellman’s noirish “Road to Nowhere” follows a moviemaker as he creates a film based on a true-crime story of insurance fraud in North Carolina.

results.headline: ‘Just Like Us’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Just Like Us

results.summary_short: “Just Like Us,” a documentary by Ahmed Ahmed, the Egyptian-American comic, is a lightweight argument for broader minds and thicker skins.

results.headline: Hey, Guys, Let’s Make a Monster Flick

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Super 8

results.summary_short: In J. J. Abrams’s “Super 8,” teenagers making a zombie movie in 1979 discover something even stranger than the undead.

results.headline: A Rural Struggle for Subsistence, Rooted in Dignity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Agrarian Utopia

results.summary_short: Uruphong Raksasad’s “Agrarian Utopia” focuses on two families of farmers in Thailand.

results.headline: Living a Drug Life in a World of Snow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reindeerspotting: Escape from the Santaland

results.summary_short: Joonas Neuvonen’s documentary, “Reindeerspotting: Escape From Santaland,” tracks a group of addicts in Finland and what they do to feed their habit.

results.headline: The Trick an Animal Cannot Learn: How to Be Wild Again

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Lucky Elephant

results.summary_short: A man and his elephant, their long relationship and their bittersweet parting form the center of this documentary.

results.headline: An Environmental Horror Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Mountain

results.summary_short: In “The Last Mountain,” Bill Haney looks at the fight over mountaintop removal to mine coal in West Virginia.

results.headline: The Power of Voices Lifted in Song

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rejoice and Shout

results.summary_short: “Rejoice and Shout,” a historical survey of African-American gospel music, illustrates how it evolved out of the fusion of plantation work songs and Christian hymns.

results.headline: Born That Way, and Proud of It

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of X-Men: First Class

results.summary_short: This latest installment of the “X-Men” series reaches back to the early 1960s for an origin story of mutants.

results.headline: Friends, Football and Fun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turkey Bowl

results.summary_short: “Turkey Bowl,” a quirky offering from Kyle Smith, is little more than a touch football game among friends.

results.headline: Coming of Age, and Then to Terms

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Submarine

results.summary_short: Richard Ayoade’s debut feature, “Submarine,” follows a Welsh schoolboy’s coming of age as he experiences first love, family trouble and stray encounters with the weirdness of the world.

results.headline: Fighting Losing Battles Against Isolation
results.display_title: Some Days Are Better Than Others

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Some Days Are Better Than Others

results.summary_short: The musicians Carrie Brownstein and James Mercer star in “Some Days Are Better Than Others,” as young people fighting losing battles against isolation.

results.headline: Alone to Face the Fallout From a Son’s Horrific Crime

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beautiful Boy

results.summary_short: A married couple’s bottled-up tensions are blasted open as they cope with their son’s shooting rampage and suicide.

results.headline: Reliving a Drug Dealer’s Halcyon Days

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Nice

results.summary_short: “Mr. Nice” reconstructs the life and high times of Howard Marks, a notorious Welsh drug dealer who went by the alias Donald Nice.

results.headline: The Dos and Don’ts of ‘I Do’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love, Wedding, Marriage

results.summary_short: Dermot Mulroney’s directorial debut, “Love, Wedding, Marriage,” stars Mandy Moore as a psychologist trying to save her parents’ marriage.

results.headline: On a Mediterranean Cruise Ship Steered by a Godardian Crew

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Film Socialisme

results.summary_short: “Film Socialisme,” Jean-Luc Godard’s latest work to arrive in America, is an assemblage of vignettes, allusions and tracts, by turns provocative, grating, gorgeous and tiresome.

results.headline: Banking and Bad Behavior

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Empire Of Silver

results.summary_short: “Empire of Silver,” Christina Yao’s melodrama, follows a powerful Chinese merchant family in the late 19th century.
